canonical_explanation.text:
Health is a state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being, not merely the absence of disease. Diseases are caused by a variety of pathogens including bacteria, viruses, protozoans, helminths, and fungi. Common bacterial diseases include typhoid (caused by Salmonella typhi, diagnosed by Widal test) and pneumonia (caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae). Important protozoan diseases include malaria (caused by Plasmodium species, transmitted by female Anopheles mosquito, characterised by recurring fever) and amoebiasis or amoebic dysentery (caused by Entamoeba histolytica). Helminthic diseases include ascariasis (caused by Ascaris lumbricoides, the round worm) and filariasis or elephantiasis (caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and W. malayi, transmitted by Culex mosquitoes). Ringworm is a common fungal infection caused by Microsporum, Trichophyton, and Epidermophyton. Prevention of diseases involves maintaining personal hygiene, proper sanitation, vector control, and vaccination.

Immunity is the body's ability to resist pathogens. Innate immunity is non-specific and includes physical barriers (skin, mucous membranes), physiological barriers (acid in stomach, lysozyme in tears), cellular barriers (phagocytes, natural killer cells), and cytokine barriers (interferons). Adaptive (acquired) immunity is pathogen-specific and has memory. It is of two types: humoral immunity (mediated by B-lymphocytes and antibodies) and cell-mediated immunity (mediated by T-lymphocytes). Primary immune response is slower and weaker; secondary immune response is faster and stronger due to memory cells. Vaccination (immunisation) is based on the principle of immunological memory — weakened or killed pathogens (antigens) are introduced to stimulate antibody production without causing disease. AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) is caused by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus), a retrovirus that attacks helper T-cells (CD4+), leading to immunodeficiency. Cancer is the uncontrolled proliferation of cells; it can be benign (non-spreading) or malignant (metastatic). Carcinogens include physical agents (UV rays, X-rays), chemical agents (tobacco smoke, aflatoxins), and biological agents (oncogenic viruses). Drugs and alcohol abuse adversely affect physical and mental health, and awareness programmes are essential for prevention.
rules: Typhoid: caused by Salmonella typhi; diagnosed by Widal test; sustained high fever, intestinal perforation in severe cases
Malaria: caused by Plasmodium (vivax, falciparum, malariae, ovale); transmitted by female Anopheles mosquito; cyclic high fever with chills
Pneumonia: caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae; infects alveoli of lungs; fever, chills, cough with mucus
Amoebiasis: caused by Entamoeba histolytica; transmitted through contaminated food/water; abdominal pain, constipation alternating with diarrhoea
Ascariasis: caused by Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm); internal bleeding, muscular pain, anaemia; transmitted through contaminated soil/food
Filariasis (elephantiasis): caused by Wuchereria bancrofti/malayi; transmitted by Culex mosquito; chronic swelling of lower limbs
Innate immunity: non-specific, present at birth; includes physical, physiological, cellular, and cytokine barriers
Adaptive immunity: specific, acquired after birth; humoral (B-cells, antibodies) and cell-mediated (T-cells); has immunological memory
Vaccination introduces weakened/killed pathogens to stimulate immune response and memory without causing disease
AIDS: caused by HIV (retrovirus); destroys CD4+ helper T-cells; transmitted through blood, sexual contact, mother to child
Cancer: uncontrolled cell growth; benign (localised) vs malignant (metastatic); caused by carcinogens (physical, chemical, biological)
Drugs of abuse include opioids, cannabinoids, cocaine; addiction causes physical and psychological dependence; awareness is key to prevention

questions.question_text: Typhoid fever is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Typhoid fever is caused by the bacterium Salmonella typhi. It is transmitted through contaminated food and water (faecal-oral route). The pathogen enters through the small intestine and reaches other organs via blood. Diagnosis is confirmed by the Widal test.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Streptococcus pneumoniae causes pneumonia. Plasmodium vivax causes malaria. Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebiasis (amoebic dysentery). Typhoid is specifically caused by Salmonella typhi.

questions.question_text: Malaria is transmitted to humans by the bite of:
questions.explanation_correct: Malaria is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected female Anopheles mosquito. The mosquito acts as the vector and the definitive host (sexual reproduction of Plasmodium occurs in the mosquito). Only female mosquitoes bite, as they need blood for egg development.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Male mosquitoes do not bite; they feed on nectar. Female Culex mosquitoes transmit filariasis. Female Aedes mosquitoes transmit dengue and chikungunya. Malaria is specifically transmitted by female Anopheles.

questions.question_text: The diagnostic test for typhoid is:
questions.explanation_correct: The Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever. It detects the presence of antibodies (agglutinins) against Salmonella typhi antigens (O and H antigens) in the patient's serum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ELISA is used for detecting antibodies against HIV and other pathogens. Western blot is a confirmatory test for HIV. Mantoux test is used for tuberculosis diagnosis. The Widal test is specific to typhoid.

questions.question_text: Amoebiasis (amoebic dysentery) is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Amoebiasis (amoebic dysentery) is caused by the protozoan Entamoeba histolytica. It is transmitted through contaminated food and water containing the cysts of the parasite. Symptoms include abdominal pain, cramps, and constipation alternating with diarrhoea.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plasmodium falciparum causes malignant malaria. Wuchereria bancrofti causes filariasis. Ascaris lumbricoides causes ascariasis. Amoebiasis is specifically caused by Entamoeba histolytica.

questions.question_text: Filariasis (elephantiasis) is transmitted by:
questions.explanation_correct: Filariasis (elephantiasis) is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and W. malayi. It is transmitted by the bite of female Culex mosquitoes. The worms block the lymphatic vessels, causing chronic swelling of the lower limbs, scrotum, and other body parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Anopheles mosquitoes transmit malaria. Houseflies are mechanical vectors for diseases like typhoid and cholera. Sandflies transmit kala-azar (leishmaniasis). Culex mosquitoes specifically transmit filariasis.

questions.question_text: The infective stage of Plasmodium that enters the human body through a mosquito bite is:
questions.explanation_correct: Sporozoites are the infective stage of Plasmodium. When an infected female Anopheles mosquito bites a human, it injects sporozoites from its salivary glands into the human bloodstream. The sporozoites then travel to the liver to begin their life cycle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gametocytes are the sexual stage that develops in human RBCs and are taken up by the mosquito. Merozoites are released from liver cells and infect RBCs. Trophozoites are the feeding stage in RBCs. Sporozoites are the specific infective form entering the human body.

questions.question_text: Which of the following diseases is caused by a helminth (worm)?
questions.explanation_correct: Ascariasis is caused by the helminth (roundworm) Ascaris lumbricoides. It is an intestinal parasitic infection transmitted through ingestion of eggs in contaminated food, water, or soil. Symptoms include abdominal pain, nausea, and in severe cases, intestinal blockage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Typhoid is a bacterial disease. Malaria is a protozoan disease. Pneumonia is a bacterial disease. Ascariasis is the helminthic disease among these options.

questions.question_text: Ringworm in humans is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Despite its name, ringworm is not caused by a worm. It is a fungal infection (dermatophytosis) caused by fungi of the genera Microsporum, Trichophyton, and Epidermophyton. It appears as dry, scaly, circular lesions on the skin, nails, or scalp.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ringworm is not caused by Ascaris (a roundworm) or any worm at all. It is not bacterial or viral. It is a fungal infection that gets its name from the ring-shaped lesions it produces on the skin.

questions.question_text: The Plasmodium species that causes the most severe (malignant) form of malaria is:
questions.explanation_correct: Plasmodium falciparum causes the most dangerous and potentially fatal form of malaria, known as malignant tertian malaria. It can lead to cerebral malaria, severe anaemia, and organ failure. P. vivax causes benign tertian malaria, which is less severe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P. vivax is the most common species in India but causes a milder form. P. ovale is rare and causes mild malaria. P. malariae causes quartan malaria. P. falciparum is specifically responsible for the most severe form.

questions.question_text: Which of the following diseases and their causative organisms is INCORRECTLY matched?
questions.explanation_correct: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, P. ovale), NOT by Entamoeba histolytica. Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebiasis (amoebic dysentery). All other matchings are correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Typhoid is correctly matched with Salmonella typhi. Pneumonia is correctly matched with Streptococcus pneumoniae. Filariasis is correctly matched with Wuchereria bancrofti. The incorrect match is malaria with Entamoeba histolytica.

questions.question_text: During the life cycle of Plasmodium, asexual reproduction occurs in:

options.text: The salivary glands of the mosquito
The liver and RBCs of the human host

questions.explanation_correct: In Plasmodium, asexual reproduction (schizogony) occurs in the human host — first in the liver cells (pre-erythrocytic cycle) and then in the red blood cells (erythrocytic cycle), producing merozoites. Sexual reproduction occurs in the mosquito (definitive host).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sexual reproduction (formation and fusion of gametes) occurs in the gut of the mosquito. Sporozoites accumulate in the salivary glands. Plasmodium does not reproduce outside its hosts. The human is the intermediate host for asexual reproduction.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a correct prevention measure for malaria?

options.text: Avoiding mosquito bites by using bed nets and insecticides

questions.explanation_correct: Since malaria is transmitted by the bite of female Anopheles mosquitoes, the primary prevention involves avoiding mosquito bites — using insecticide-treated bed nets, mosquito repellents, eliminating stagnant water (breeding sites), and indoor residual spraying.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Drinking boiled water prevents waterborne diseases like typhoid and cholera. Handwashing prevents faecal-oral transmission. Avoiding contaminated food prevents typhoid and amoebiasis. Malaria prevention requires mosquito bite avoidance.

questions.question_text: Pneumonia primarily infects which organ of the body?
questions.explanation_correct: Pneumonia is an infection of the lungs, specifically the alveoli. Fluid (pus and other material) fills the alveoli, causing difficulty in breathing, fever, chills, and cough with mucus. It is caused by bacteria like Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The liver is affected by hepatitis. The kidneys are affected by nephritis. The intestine is affected by diseases like typhoid and amoebiasis. Pneumonia specifically affects the lungs (alveoli).

questions.question_text: Which of the following organisms causes both intestinal and extra-intestinal disease in humans?
questions.explanation_correct: Entamoeba histolytica primarily causes intestinal amoebiasis (dysentery) but can also cause extra-intestinal disease, most notably amoebic liver abscess, when the parasite invades the liver through the portal circulation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ascaris mainly causes intestinal disease. Wuchereria causes lymphatic filariasis. Microsporum causes skin infections. Entamoeba histolytica can invade beyond the intestine to affect the liver and other organs.

questions.question_text: The common cold is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: The common cold is caused by rhinoviruses. It affects the nose and respiratory passage but not the lungs. Symptoms include nasal congestion, sore throat, cough, and headache. It spreads through droplets from coughs and sneezes of infected persons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Streptococcus causes pneumonia and sore throat. Haemophilus influenzae causes pneumonia and meningitis. Staphylococcus causes skin infections and food poisoning. Rhinoviruses specifically cause the common cold.

questions.question_text: Which vector is common to both dengue and chikungunya?
questions.explanation_correct: Both dengue and chikungunya are transmitted by the Aedes mosquito (primarily Aedes aegypti). These viral diseases share the same vector, and outbreaks often occur together in tropical and subtropical regions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Anopheles transmits malaria. Culex transmits filariasis. Sandfly transmits leishmaniasis (kala-azar). Aedes mosquitoes specifically transmit both dengue and chikungunya.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of innate immunity?

options.text: Skin acting as a physical barrier against pathogens
Memory cells after first exposure to a pathogen

questions.explanation_correct: Skin is a component of innate (natural) immunity. It acts as a physical barrier preventing the entry of pathogens into the body. Innate immunity is non-specific, present from birth, and does not improve upon repeated exposure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vaccination stimulates adaptive immunity. Antibody production is part of adaptive (humoral) immunity. Memory cells are a feature of adaptive immunity. Skin as a barrier is an example of innate, non-specific defence.

questions.question_text: Humoral immunity is mediated by:
questions.explanation_correct: Humoral immunity (also called antibody-mediated immunity) is mediated by B-lymphocytes. When B-cells encounter an antigen, they differentiate into plasma cells that produce antibodies (immunoglobulins) which circulate in the blood and lymph to neutralise pathogens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: T-lymphocytes mediate cell-mediated immunity (CMI). Macrophages are part of innate immunity and also act as antigen-presenting cells. Natural killer cells are part of innate immunity. B-cells and antibodies are the key players in humoral immunity.

questions.question_text: The secondary immune response is faster and stronger than the primary response due to:

options.text: Presence of memory B and T cells from the first exposure
Weakening of the pathogen over time

questions.explanation_correct: During the primary immune response, memory B-cells and memory T-cells are generated. Upon subsequent exposure to the same pathogen, these memory cells are rapidly activated, producing a faster, stronger, and more prolonged immune response. This is the basis of immunological memory.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pathogen does not become weaker. Skin thickness does not change. The number of pathogens in the second exposure may not be different. Memory cells from the first exposure are responsible for the enhanced secondary response.

questions.question_text: Vaccination works on the principle of:
questions.explanation_correct: Vaccination introduces weakened, killed, or subunit pathogens (antigens) into the body. This stimulates the immune system to produce antibodies and memory cells without causing the actual disease. Upon subsequent real infection, the memory cells mount a rapid and effective immune response.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Innate immunity is non-specific and not enhanced by vaccination. Passive immunity involves receiving ready-made antibodies (e.g., mother's milk). Tolerance means the immune system does not respond. Vaccination relies on active immunity and immunological memory.

questions.question_text: Colostrum (the first milk from the mother) provides which type of immunity to the newborn?
questions.explanation_correct: Colostrum is rich in antibodies, particularly IgA. The mother passes these ready-made antibodies to the newborn, providing immediate but temporary protection. This is passive immunity because the baby's immune system does not produce the antibodies itself.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Active immunity requires the body to produce its own antibodies. Cell-mediated immunity involves T-cells. Innate immunity is already present at birth. Colostrum provides passive immunity through the transfer of maternal antibodies.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a physiological barrier of innate immunity?
questions.explanation_correct: Acid in the stomach (HCl) is a physiological barrier of innate immunity. It destroys most of the microorganisms that enter with food. Other physiological barriers include lysozyme in tears and saliva, and bile juice in the intestine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Skin is a physical barrier. Neutrophils and macrophages are cellular barriers. Interferons are cytokine barriers. Acid in the stomach is a physiological (chemical) barrier of innate immunity.

questions.question_text: Cell-mediated immunity (CMI) is primarily mediated by:
questions.explanation_correct: Cell-mediated immunity (CMI) is mediated by T-lymphocytes. There are different types: helper T-cells (CD4+) activate other immune cells, cytotoxic T-cells (CD8+) kill infected cells directly, and regulatory T-cells suppress excessive immune responses. CMI is important in defence against intracellular pathogens, transplant rejection, and tumour surveillance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: B-lymphocytes and antibodies mediate humoral immunity, not CMI. Complement proteins are part of the innate immune system. T-lymphocytes are the primary mediators of cell-mediated immunity.

questions.question_text: An allergic reaction is caused by an exaggerated immune response to:
questions.explanation_correct: Allergy is an exaggerated immune response to certain environmental substances called allergens (e.g., pollen, dust mites, certain foods). The immune system produces IgE antibodies that cause mast cells to release histamine and other chemicals, leading to symptoms like sneezing, itching, and inflammation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Immune response against self-antigens causes autoimmune diseases, not allergies. Cancer cells trigger immune surveillance. Pathogenic bacteria cause normal immune responses. Allergies involve overreaction to harmless allergens.

questions.question_text: Antibodies are proteins that belong to which class of proteins?
questions.explanation_correct: Antibodies are immunoglobulins (Ig) — they belong to the globulin class of proteins. There are five classes of immunoglobulins: IgA, IgD, IgE, IgG, and IgM. Each has a specific role in the immune response. IgG is the most abundant in blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Albumins are transport proteins in blood. Histones are DNA-packaging proteins. Collagen is a structural protein. Antibodies are specifically immunoglobulins — a type of gamma globulin.

questions.question_text: Which type of immunity is provided when a person receives anti-venom injection after a snake bite?
questions.explanation_correct: Anti-venom injection provides ready-made antibodies against the snake venom. Since the person's immune system does not produce these antibodies itself, this is passive immunity. As it is given artificially (through injection), it is artificially acquired passive immunity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Active immunity requires the body to produce its own antibodies. Naturally acquired passive immunity comes from the mother (e.g., via placenta or colostrum). Vaccination provides artificially acquired active immunity. Anti-venom provides artificially acquired passive immunity.

questions.question_text: Autoimmune disease occurs when:

options.text: The immune system fails to respond to any antigen
The immune system attacks the body's own cells and tissues
The body produces too many white blood cells

questions.explanation_correct: In autoimmune diseases, the immune system mistakenly identifies the body's own cells and tissues as foreign and mounts an immune response against them. Examples include rheumatoid arthritis, type 1 diabetes, and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Failure to respond to antigens is immunodeficiency, not autoimmunity. Producing too many WBCs could be leukaemia. Vaccine side effects are different from autoimmune disease. Autoimmunity specifically involves self-attack.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the four types of barriers in innate immunity?

options.text: Physical (skin, mucous membrane), physiological (acid, lysozyme), cellular (phagocytes, NK cells), cytokine (interferons)

questions.explanation_correct: Innate immunity has four types of barriers: Physical barriers (skin, mucous membranes), Physiological barriers (acid in stomach, lysozyme in tears, bile), Cellular barriers (phagocytes like neutrophils and macrophages, natural killer cells), and Cytokine barriers (interferons that protect non-infected cells from viral infection).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antibodies and B-cells are part of adaptive immunity, not innate. T-cells are also adaptive. RBCs and platelets are not immune barriers. The correct innate barriers include skin, acid/lysozyme, phagocytes/NK cells, and interferons.

questions.question_text: Interferons are produced by virus-infected cells to:

options.text: Protect neighbouring uninfected cells from viral infection

questions.explanation_correct: Interferons are cytokine proteins produced by virus-infected cells. They do not directly kill the virus but signal neighbouring uninfected cells to activate their antiviral defences, making them resistant to viral infection. This limits the spread of the virus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Interferons do not directly kill viruses. While they may indirectly influence B-cells, their primary role is protecting uninfected cells. Fever (increased temperature) is caused by pyrogens, not interferons.

questions.question_text: Edward Jenner is known for developing the first vaccine against:
questions.explanation_correct: Edward Jenner developed the first vaccine in 1796 against smallpox. He observed that milkmaids who had contracted cowpox did not get smallpox. He inoculated a boy with cowpox material and later showed that the boy was immune to smallpox.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Jonas Salk developed the polio vaccine. Louis Pasteur developed the rabies vaccine. Albert Calmette and Camille Guerin developed the BCG vaccine for tuberculosis. Jenner's historic contribution was the smallpox vaccine.

questions.question_text: AIDS is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) is caused by the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV). HIV is a retrovirus that contains RNA as its genetic material and uses reverse transcriptase to produce DNA from RNA inside the host cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: AIDS is not caused by bacteria, protozoans, or fungi. It is specifically caused by HIV, a retrovirus belonging to the Lentivirus group.

questions.question_text: HIV primarily attacks which type of immune cells?
questions.explanation_correct: HIV primarily targets and destroys helper T-cells (CD4+ T-lymphocytes), which are crucial for coordinating the immune response. As CD4+ cell count drops below 200 cells/µL, the immune system becomes severely compromised, leading to opportunistic infections characteristic of AIDS.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While HIV can also infect macrophages, its primary target is helper T-cells (CD4+). B-lymphocytes are not the primary target. RBCs do not have CD4 receptors. The depletion of helper T-cells is the hallmark of AIDS.

questions.question_text: HIV is transmitted through all of the following EXCEPT:

options.text: Unprotected sexual contact with an infected person
Casual contact like shaking hands or sharing food

questions.explanation_correct: HIV is NOT transmitted through casual contact such as shaking hands, hugging, sharing food, or using the same toilet. HIV is transmitted through unprotected sexual contact, contaminated blood (needles, transfusions), and from an infected mother to her child during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unprotected sexual contact, sharing contaminated needles, and infected blood transfusions are all established modes of HIV transmission. Casual contact does NOT transmit HIV.

questions.question_text: Cancer cells differ from normal cells in that they show:

options.text: Uncontrolled cell division and loss of contact inhibition
Slower division rate than normal cells

questions.explanation_correct: Cancer cells show uncontrolled proliferation due to the loss of contact inhibition — the property that makes normal cells stop dividing when they come in contact with neighbouring cells. Cancer cells continue to divide, forming tumours.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Contact inhibition is a property of normal cells, not cancer cells. Cancer cells divide faster, not slower, than normal cells. Cancer cells can grow indefinitely in culture (immortalised). Loss of contact inhibition is a hallmark of cancer.

questions.question_text: A malignant tumour is different from a benign tumour because it:

options.text: Remains localised and does not spread
Shows metastasis — spreads to distant body parts through blood and lymph

questions.explanation_correct: A malignant tumour is cancerous and shows metastasis — cancer cells break away from the primary tumour, travel through blood and lymph, and establish secondary tumours in distant organs. Benign tumours are localised and do not metastasise.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remaining localised describes benign tumours. Malignant tumours are cancerous, not non-cancerous. Malignant tumours often grow rapidly. The key distinguishing feature of malignancy is metastasis.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a confirmatory diagnostic test for HIV/AIDS?
questions.explanation_correct: ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) is used as a screening test for HIV. Western blot is used as a confirmatory test. It detects specific antibodies against HIV proteins by separating them by size using gel electrophoresis and then probing with patient's serum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Widal test is for typhoid. ELISA is the initial screening test, not the confirmatory test. PCR can detect viral RNA but Western blot is the standard confirmatory test for HIV diagnosis.

questions.question_text: Oncogenes are:

options.text: Normal genes that have been altered to cause cancer
Genes present only in cancer cells

questions.explanation_correct: Oncogenes are altered (mutated) forms of normal genes called proto-oncogenes. Proto-oncogenes regulate normal cell growth and division. When they undergo mutations or become overactivated, they become oncogenes that promote uncontrolled cell growth, leading to cancer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tumour suppressor genes (not oncogenes) inhibit cell growth. Oncogenes originate from proto-oncogenes present in all normal cells. DNA repair genes are different from oncogenes. Oncogenes are specifically mutated proto-oncogenes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a mode of transmission of HIV?

options.text: From infected mother to child through placenta
Sharing infected needles during intravenous drug use

questions.explanation_correct: HIV is NOT transmitted through mosquito bites. Mosquitoes do not transmit HIV because the virus cannot survive or replicate inside mosquitoes. HIV is transmitted through sexual contact, contaminated blood/needles, and from mother to child.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mother-to-child transmission through placenta, infected blood transfusion, and sharing infected needles are all established modes of HIV transmission. Mosquito bites do NOT transmit HIV.

questions.question_text: Which of the following substances is a known chemical carcinogen?
questions.explanation_correct: Tobacco smoke contains many chemical carcinogens, including polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (like benzpyrene), N-nitrosamines, and aromatic amines. These chemicals cause mutations in DNA leading to cancer, particularly lung cancer. Tobacco use is the leading preventable cause of cancer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vitamin C is an antioxidant and not a carcinogen. Glucose is a normal nutrient. Sodium chloride is common salt. Tobacco smoke is a well-established chemical carcinogen.

questions.question_text: The enzyme reverse transcriptase found in HIV is responsible for:

options.text: Synthesising DNA from an RNA template
Synthesising RNA from a DNA template

questions.explanation_correct: Reverse transcriptase is an enzyme unique to retroviruses like HIV. It synthesises complementary DNA (cDNA) from the viral RNA template. This DNA is then integrated into the host cell's genome by the enzyme integrase, allowing the virus to hijack the cell's machinery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: RNA from DNA template is normal transcription (done by RNA polymerase). Reverse transcriptase does not break down or replicate host DNA. Its specific function is to convert viral RNA into DNA — the reverse of normal transcription.

questions.question_text: Which of the following cancers is associated with tobacco use?

options.text: Liver cancer caused by hepatitis B
Skin cancer caused by UV radiation

questions.explanation_correct: Lung cancer is strongly associated with tobacco smoking. Cigarette smoke contains carcinogens like benzo[a]pyrene and N-nitrosamines. Tobacco use is also linked to cancers of the mouth, throat, oesophagus, bladder, and pancreas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Liver cancer from hepatitis B is a viral cause. Leukaemia from benzene is a chemical exposure at workplaces. Skin cancer from UV is a physical cause. Lung cancer is the classic tobacco-associated cancer.

questions.question_text: Metastasis in cancer refers to:

options.text: Rapid cell division at one location
Spread of cancer cells to distant organs through blood and lymph

questions.explanation_correct: Metastasis is the process by which cancer cells detach from the primary tumour, enter the bloodstream or lymphatic system, and establish secondary tumours (metastatic tumours) in distant organs. It is the hallmark of malignant cancer and the main cause of cancer-related deaths.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Programmed cell death is apoptosis. Rapid division at one location describes a localised tumour. Benign tumours do not metastasise. Metastasis specifically refers to the spread of malignant cells to distant sites.

questions.question_text: Opioids are drugs derived from:
questions.explanation_correct: Opioids (morphine, heroin, codeine) are derived from the opium poppy plant (Papaver somniferum). Morphine is a strong analgesic (painkiller). Heroin (diacetylmorphine) is a highly addictive drug that depresses the central nervous system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cannabis sativa is the source of cannabinoids (marijuana, hashish). Erythroxylum coca is the source of cocaine. Atropa belladonna is the source of atropine. Opioids specifically come from Papaver somniferum.

questions.question_text: Cannabinoids are obtained from the plant:
questions.explanation_correct: Cannabinoids (marijuana, hashish, charas, ganja) are obtained from the inflorescences and leaves of Cannabis sativa. They act on cannabinoid receptors in the brain, affecting perception, mood, and cognition.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Papaver somniferum is the source of opioids. Erythroxylum coca is the source of cocaine. Nicotiana tabacum is the source of nicotine (tobacco). Cannabis sativa specifically produces cannabinoids.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a biological carcinogen?
questions.explanation_correct: Oncogenic (tumour-causing) viruses are biological carcinogens. Examples include Human Papillomavirus (HPV) causing cervical cancer, Hepatitis B virus causing liver cancer, and Epstein-Barr virus associated with Burkitt's lymphoma. These viruses can transform normal cells into cancerous cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: UV radiation is a physical carcinogen. Aflatoxins and tobacco smoke are chemical carcinogens. Oncogenic viruses are specifically biological carcinogens that can insert their genetic material into host cells and activate oncogenes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of HIV infection in the human body?

options.text: HIV binds to CD4 receptors → viral RNA enters cell → reverse transcriptase makes DNA → viral DNA integrates into host DNA → new viruses produced
HIV binds to CD8 receptors → viral DNA enters cell → new viruses produced
HIV enters RBCs → replicates → destroys RBCs
HIV directly kills B-cells → no antibody production

questions.explanation_correct: HIV binds to CD4 receptors on helper T-cells using its gp120 protein. The viral RNA is released into the cell, where reverse transcriptase converts it to cDNA. The viral DNA integrates into the host genome by integrase. The host machinery then produces new viral RNA and proteins, assembling new virions that bud out to infect more cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HIV binds to CD4 receptors, not CD8. HIV does not enter RBCs (they lack CD4 receptors). HIV's primary target is helper T-cells, not B-cells directly. The correct sequence involves CD4 binding, reverse transcription, integration, and new virus production.

questions.question_text: Which type of white blood cell is responsible for engulfing and destroying pathogens by phagocytosis?
questions.explanation_correct: Neutrophils and macrophages are the primary phagocytic cells of the innate immune system. They engulf and destroy pathogens through phagocytosis — surrounding the pathogen with their cell membrane and digesting it using lysosomal enzymes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eosinophils mainly fight parasitic infections. Basophils release histamine in allergic reactions. Lymphocytes (B and T cells) are involved in adaptive immunity. Neutrophils and macrophages are the key phagocytic cells.

questions.question_text: Drug addiction leads to all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: Drug addiction does NOT enhance immune function. In fact, drug and alcohol abuse weakens the immune system, making the body more susceptible to infections. Addiction causes physical and psychological dependence, withdrawal symptoms, and damage to organs like the liver, kidneys, and brain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Physical/psychological dependence, withdrawal symptoms, and organ damage are all well-documented effects of drug addiction. Enhanced immune function is incorrect — drug abuse actually suppresses immunity.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly differentiates active immunity from passive immunity?

options.text: Active immunity provides immediate protection; passive immunity takes time to develop
Active immunity involves the body producing its own antibodies; passive immunity involves receiving ready-made antibodies
Active immunity lasts for a shorter duration; passive immunity lasts longer
Active immunity does not involve memory cells; passive immunity generates memory

questions.explanation_correct: Active immunity involves the body's own immune system producing antibodies and memory cells in response to an antigen (through infection or vaccination). Passive immunity involves receiving pre-formed antibodies from an external source (e.g., mother's milk, anti-serum injection) and does not generate memory.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Active immunity takes time to develop but provides long-lasting protection. Passive immunity provides immediate but short-lived protection. Active immunity generates memory cells; passive immunity does not.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of cancer?
questions.explanation_correct: Cancer treatment involves three main approaches: surgery (removal of the tumour), radiation therapy (using ionising radiation to kill cancer cells), and chemotherapy (using cytotoxic drugs that kill dividing cells). Immunotherapy and targeted therapy are also increasingly used. The choice depends on the type and stage of cancer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antibiotics treat bacterial infections. Antiviral drugs treat viral infections. Anti-allergic drugs treat allergies. Cancer is treated through surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy.
